thread.title: Forget VW — GM and Ford stocks are ‘dirt cheap’ - MarketWatch
thread.title_full: Forget VW — GM and Ford stocks are ‘dirt cheap’ - MarketWatch

author: yahoo
title: Forget VW — GM and Ford stocks are ‘dirt cheap’ - MarketWatch
text:
In July 2014, I suggested that investors let Ford and General Motors “ drive their portfolios .”
It hasn’t worked out well — so far. With dividends reinvested, shares of Ford Motor Co. F, -0.88% have dropped 19% since July 25, 2014, when the article was published, while General Motors Co. GM, -0.10% is down 11%.
FactSet Twelve-month total returns, with dividends reinvested, for Ford and GM. Egg on my face? Not necessarily, considering that a solid long-term investment can take a few years to play out. And the two stocks look attractive, even now:
Company Closing price - Sept. 23 Annual dividend Dividend yield Consensus 2016 EPS estimate Forward price-to-earnings ratio Ford Motor Co. $13.68 $0.60 4.39% $1.93 7.1 General Motors Co. $29.72 $1.44 4.85% $5.10 5.8 Source: FactSet To put those price-to-earnings ratios in perspective, the S&P 500 Index SPX, -0.05% trades for 16.4 times weighted aggregate consensus 2016 estimates, according to FactSet.
Ford and GM don’t trade much higher, on a P/E basis, than the beleaguered Volkswagen AG VOW, -2.82% whose earnings will be wiped out this year by charges related to the diesel-emissions scandal . VW trades for 5.2 times the consensus 2016 earnings estimate, while its American Depositary Receipts VLKAY, -5.45% trade slightly higher, at 5.3. 
Read: Think VW’s stock can make you rich on a rebound? Think again 
BWM AG BMW, +4.11% has its own emissions problem , and its stock trades for 8.3 times the consensus 2016 EPS estimate.
Yes, the auto-manufacturing business is cyclical, and it’s capital-intensive, which helps explain the low P/E ratios for Ford and GM. But both companies are in a sweet spot, with U.S. auto sales rising to an annual rate of 17.81 million in August, a 10-year high.
Ford expects pre-tax profit to range from $8.5 billion to $9.5 billion, compared with $4.3 billion in 2014, when sales declined as the company prepared to release a slew of new models, and $7 billion in 2013.
GM’s pre-tax income for the first half of 2015 was $3.2 billion, and CFO Charles Stevens said during the company’s earnings call July 23: “We expect to sustain our first-half performance throughout the rest of the year.” 
In comparison, GM booked a pre-tax loss of $398 million in the first half 2014, when it was hit with massive expenses from 29 million vehicle recalls . During the first half of 2013, GM’s pre-tax earnings came to $2.1 billion.
